utterances: Good advice to the Democrats and Obama.
David Brooks, you have a column today in which you long for something between bipartisanship and a pox on both your houses.
Do you see any prospect of Barack Obama becoming what you call an updated, saner Ross Perot?
Typical incoherence on my part.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
No, I mean a lot of this debate about the State Union would he moved to the center?
And the axis was center left.
Well, to me, the axis really should be inside-outside.
We're in a moment of unprecedented distrust of Washington.
And that is where the country is.
And I thought - and the question is does anybody in Washington reflect that distrust and do they have a solution to the genuine problem which is the Washington broken?
We've tried to reform Social Security, immigration, health care, energy, all those things are failures or likely failures.
And so I thought the president took some steps to showing I will change Washington, I am not a typical Washington insider.
He adopted some policies, which are kind of independent friendly, freeze on spending, nuclear power, offshore drilling, that's non-orthodox stuff.
Nonetheless, I don't think he went nearly far enough.
The country is just in a rage about Washington, and he is behind that, as are the Republicans, but at least they can say we're against Washington.
He has to try to say Washington is terrible, trust us to run more of the country and that's a contradiction.
I agree with David on this, the need for him to distance himself from Washington.
At the end of that speech, you wondered does Barack Obama live in Washington anymore because he really was trying to identify with that anger.

And I think part of his strategy here is to make an argument that, wait a minute, these Republicans who have been giving me all this grief and the statement that led to this segment, these guys are at least as responsible for the mess we have here.
So, he's trying to push back against them, which is something he really hadn't done very much of in 2009.
But they could at least say Washington is broken, let's go get all the power out of Washington.
That's a reasonably simple message.
To me, the core moral corruption is the deficits.
You've got to tackle the deficits in a very hardcore way.
And that means Republican saying we need tax increases, Democrats saying we need spending increase, we're not even close to that.
Yes.
I still am.
Were you surprised to...
I think she was labor - secretary of labor, I believe.
I think Griffin said that he asked Stern to stay on, and Griffin and Stern said the same and that he didn't want to.
I don't know why he left.

But, you know, what is true is that the budgets are pretty tight and part of the reason that Mars rover was asked to take a $4 million cut was that their cost overruns for the Mars Science Lab, which is another rover destined for Mars, and you know, first, they try and take it out on some of the other part of the program before…
Right.
…looking, sort of, NASA-wide.
So, you know, it's a tough job.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But you would think…
Do you want it?

Well, I have to give, you know, Dr. Griffin credit for realizing he's shutting down if he would have had to cripple probably the most conspicuous and loved program that NASA has at the moment, you know.
It is loved.
I mean, obviously, people love it, but I think they love it, you know, in large part because it's been up there for four years, and they're still going, right?
Right.
You know, I do - people aren't making a decision based on the science that it's putting out today and whether that's worth the money versus something else, you know.
They just love the rovers - that's what they know -like a Hubble.
And - all right, let's move on.
Let's move on to - you're right…
Well, Pluto.
And actually, can I add that Alan Stern…
Yes.
(Soundbite of laughter)
…Alan Stern actually was, as far as I know, the highest ranking official at NASA who is an official Pluto-hugger, and he ran the New Horizons Project to go to Pluto.
And he refuses to admit that it's not a planet.
Well, we're going to get into…
A dwarf planet is…
Yeah.
…not in his vocabulary.

Well, we're going to get into that a little bit later about somebody who's actually deciding to re-come up - to come up with new kinds of criteria that will put Pluto back in, but that's good to hear.
Let's talk about the space shuttle because it had this unusually long trip to the International Space Station, right?
Yeah, they brought up part of a Japanese lab and a robot, who's Canadian.
I don't know if that means he has citizenship, but a Canadian robot named…
(Soundbite of laughter)
…Dextre with 11-foot extendable arms.
You know, you could not get more of ends of spectra for NASA operations, the much loved rovers, and who cares that the shuttle is flying to the space station, you know.
Well, maybe they'll love Dextre now.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Look, you know, NASA's in a hard spot, right?
They, you know, they have to finish the International Space Station, right?
And then there's going to be this gap after the shuttles are gone of what looks like at least five years now, where the U.S.
will not have a way to get into space, except by hitching a ride with the Russians.
So NASA's trying to juggle a lot of things and everyone said they don't have enough money to do all of them.
It's just going to be hard.
So we're going to have a finished space station.
The shuttles will be out of operation and there'll be no way for the U.S.
to get to it, except if it hitches a ride.
Right.

And you know, this is - NASA's due to hand over to Congress, shortly, a report about what this means for the workforce, and Griffin has said, you know, it's going to be tough for places like Kennedy Space Center because it's unclear what all those employees are going to do when the space shuttle's gone and it's supposed to retire in 2010.
And when you keep all those people out of work, they may go for other jobs, and that means it's hard to keep that talent with…
Maybe(ph) science correspondents.

There you go.
Well, you can moonlight a little, David.
Thank you for taking time to be with us and good luck to you.
You're welcome.
Okay, bye-bye.
NPR science correspondent David Kestenbaum talking about the shuttle.
A few months ago, David Isay, the creator of StoryCorps, got a letter from a listener.
It came after he was on the public radio show Indivisible talking about a new idea he had to get strangers with different political opinions to talk to each other.
The subject line of the email was love the show, but it was actually very critical.
David replied to the email and invited the guy to sit down for a StoryCorps interview, and the guy said yes.
Here's them talking about that first email.
